finding.description: Firewall rules that allow connections from all IP addresses on TCP port 9090 may expose CiscoSecure/WebSM services to attackers.
Firewall rules that allow connections from all IP addresses or on all ports may expose resources to attackers.

To reduce the attack surface, avoid assigning public IP addresses to your VMs. Stopped instances may still be flagged with a Public IP finding, e.g. if the network interfaces are configured to assign an ephemeral public IP on start. Ensure the network configurations for stopped instances do not include external access.
Firewall rules that allow connections from all IP addresses on TCP port 22 or SCTP port 22 may expose SSH services to attackers.

To reduce the attack surface, avoid assigning public IP addresses to your VMs. Stopped instances may still be flagged with a Public IP finding, e.g. if the network interfaces are configured to assign an ephemeral public IP on start. Ensure the network configurations for stopped instances do not include external access.

You have added 0.0.0.0/0 as an allowed network. This prefix will allow any IPv4 client to pass the network firewall and make login attempts to your instance, including clients you did not intend to allow. Clients still need valid credentials to successfully log in to your instance. Learn more at: https://cloud.google.com/sql/docs/mysql/configure-ip
Firewall rules that allow connections from all IP addresses on TCP port 3389 or UDP port 3389 may expose RDP services to attackers.

This bucket is public and can be accessed by anyone on the Internet. "allUsers" represents anyone on the Internet, and "allAuthenticatedUsers" represents anyone who is authenticated with a Google account; neither is constrained to users within your organization.

To avoid leaking sensitive data in transit through unencrypted communications, all incoming connections to your SQL database instance should use SSL. Learn more at: https://cloud.google.com/sql/docs/mysql/configure-ssl-instance

hostPath volumes mount files or directories from the host. These volumes present security risks that could lead to container escape.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-26583) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-26809) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-26642) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-41009) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.

Exposing a host port to a container potentially allows the container to intercept network traffic to a host service using that port or to bypass network access control rules, such as the rules in a NetworkPolicy.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-41009) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-26585) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.

A vulnerability (CVE-2024-26809) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.
A vulnerability (CVE-2023-52620) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.

Exposing a host port to a container potentially allows the container to intercept network traffic to a host service using that port or to bypass network access control rules, such as the rules in a NetworkPolicy.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-36978) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.

You can explicitly allow a container to run as the root user if the runAsUser or the USER directive in the image specifies the root user. The lack of preventive security controls when running as the root user increases the risk of container escape.
A Denial-of-Service (DoS) vulnerability (CVE-2023-45288) was recently discovered in multiple implementations of the HTTP/2 protocol, including the golang HTTP server used by Kubernetes.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-26925) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-39503) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-26585) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.

A remote code execution vulnerability was recently discovered in OpenSSH.  The vulnerability exploits a race condition that can be used to obtain access to a remote shell, enabling attackers to gain root access to GKE nodes. At the time of publication, exploitation is believed to be fairly difficult and take several hours per machine being attacked.

2 vulnerabilities (CVE-2023-52654,CVE-2023-52656) have been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.

Pods that share host namespaces allow Pod processes to communicate with host processes and gather host information, which could lead to a container escape.
A vulnerability (CVE-2024-26643) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.

A container can be explicitly configured to allow privilege escalation on execution. This permits a process created within the container by executing a set-user-id, set-group-id, or file capability executable to gain the privileges specified by the executable. The lack of preventive security control increases the risk of container escape.

A vulnerability (CVE-2024-36978) has been discovered in the Linux kernel that can lead to privilege escalation on Container-Optimized OS and Ubuntu nodes.

A container can be explicitly configured to allow privilege escalation on execution. This permits a process created within the container by executing a set-user-id, set-group-id, or file capability executable to gain the privileges specified by the executable. The lack of preventive security control increases the risk of container escape.

Privileged containers allow nearly unrestricted host access. They share namespaces with the host, and lack control group, seccomp, AppArmor, and capability restrictions.
